metadata.sermon_start_end: A few days ago, as I was beginning to think about this sermon for Trinity Sunday, I heard an agnostic friend refer to the activity of the Christian church as “proselytizing.” That made my blood rise just a little; without really thinking, I said, “Not proselytizing! That’s the wrong word.” [...] In him there is news so good that we cannot possibly keep it to ourselves, for he has gone before us with the Great Commission to all the peoples of the earth, and lo, Jesus is with us always, even to the end of the world. Amen.
metadata.notes: Trinity Sunday sermon delivered in 1993 at Grace Church, NYC. Context: Height of 90s multiculturalism debates.

factual_content_blue.analysis: The preacher addresses the doctrine of the Trinity not as a metaphysical puzzle but as a relational event. He correctly identifies the 'Sache' (the living Christ) as the source of the Great Commission. However, the exegetical depth is secondary to the cultural commentary. While he mentions the Greek 'evangel', the sermon relies heavily on sociological observations (Schlesinger, Myrdal) to frame the 'facts' of the Gospel. The theological content is sound—centering on the 'extra nos' of salvation—but it risks becoming a lecture on the definition of 'evangelism' versus 'religion' rather than a deep dive into the Matthean text itself. The 'blue' side serves as a corrective to cultural misconceptions of Christianity.
quotes: The doctrine of the Trinity is often criticized for being an abstraction. But it isn’t an abstraction. In the final analysis it is an event.
Evangelizing, therefore, means, 'telling good news.' It is the opposite of bad news.
The word evangel is a New Testament Greek word... It is a God-given word.
strengths: Clear distinction between 'religion' (human effort) and 'Gospel' (God's act).
Effective translation of Trinitarian dogma into relational terms.
improvement_points: More rigorous exegesis of the Matthew 28 text beyond the word 'evangel'.
Reduction of reliance on 20th-century secular historians to validate the Gospel's utility.
factual_content_blue.comprehensibility_check: High. The preacher avoids technical jargon, making the Trinity accessible through the metaphor of 'relationship'.

self_revelation_green.analysis: The preacher is remarkably transparent, revealing a personality that is intellectually engaged yet pastorally sensitive. He admits to emotional reactions ('my blood rise just a little') and personal failures (falling asleep during meditation). This vulnerability creates a high degree of authenticity. He does not present himself as a 'spiritual giant' but as a recipient of grace. There is a clear 'diaconal' quality to his self-revelation; his personal anecdotes (the letter of consolation, the encounter with William) are not ego-driven but serve to illustrate the radical nature of the Gospel. He 'leaks' a certain level of frustration with the 'cultural tsars,' showing his own position within the NYC intellectual milieu.
quotes: That made my blood rise just a little; without really thinking, I said...
As soon as I try to meditate about something, I fall asleep.
I am not saved by my spirituality... I am saved by God.
self_revelation_green.riemann_type_diagnosis: Depressive/Hysterical hybrid. He seeks harmony and closeness (Depressive) by emphasizing inclusivity and shared 'dirt,' yet he uses the pulpit with a certain narrative flair and dramatic timing (Hysterical) to engage his 'cognoscenti' audience.
self_revelation_green.diaconal_quality: The 'I' is subservient. He uses his own lack of 'spirituality' to point toward the sufficiency of Christ.
strengths: Disarming honesty about his own prayer life.
improvement_points: The 'blood rising' comment suggests a slight defensiveness that could be perceived as 'us vs. them' by the 'agnostic friend' type of listener.

relational_aspect_yellow.analysis: The relationship with the congregation is one of 'solidary teaching.' He places himself in the same boat as the listeners ('you and I,' 'our dirt'). However, there is a subtle 'teaching from above' when he critiques the 'cultural tsars' and the 'media industry.' He assumes a shared struggle with the congregation against a hostile secular environment. The use of the 'Pogo' comic strip and the story of 'William' signals a desire for a warm, intellectual, yet down-to-earth relationship. There is 'relationship noise' in his critique of multiculturalism; listeners who identify with the 'cultural tsars' might feel judged or stereotyped, despite his call for inclusivity.
quotes: William... knows the Bible at least as well as you and I.
I was a bit shaken to see them. I thought, Oh my God...
relational_aspect_yellow.relationship_noise_check: The critique of 'cultural tsars' may alienate those in the congregation who work in those very industries.
relational_aspect_yellow.attitude_indication: Solidary and intellectual; he treats the congregation as thoughtful peers.
strengths: Strong sense of 'we-identity' regarding human brokenness.
Respectful and disarming approach to interfaith encounters.
improvement_points: Be cautious of creating an 'inner circle' of Christians vs. the 'hostile' outside world.

appeal_aspect_red.analysis: The sermon is a masterclass in the 'Zuspruch' (Promise) over 'Anspruch' (Demand). The appeal is not 'be better' or 'be more multicultural,' but 'behold what God has done.' The directional force is toward trust in the 'secret ingrediment' of God's grace. He explicitly rejects the appeal to 'be religious.' The only 'demand' is the implicit call to not keep the good news secret, but even this is framed as a natural response to joy rather than a legalistic duty. He successfully avoids moralism by rooting the 'new community' in the 'eternal relationships of the Trinity' rather than human effort.
quotes: The good news of the Christian gospel, however, is for everyone.
It would be the lowest form of selfishness to hold the good news to ourselves.
They are for all the unclean: those who do not know how to pray...
appeal_aspect_red.zuspruch_vs_anspruch_balance: Dominantly Zuspruch. The Gospel is presented as a gift that precedes and enables any human action.
appeal_aspect_red.risk_of_moralism: Very low. He actively deconstructs moralism by highlighting 'dirt' as the common denominator.
strengths: Excellent theological grounding of the 'Great Commission' in grace.
improvement_points: The appeal to 'evangelize' could be more concrete—how does this look in the 'multicultural logjam' of daily NYC life?

congruence_and_disruptions.congruence_judgment: Highly congruent. The preacher's tone, personal admissions, and theological content all align to communicate a message of 'grace for the ungodly.'
congruence_and_disruptions.disruptions: Minor incongruence between the call for 'multicultural inclusivity' and the slightly polemical tone toward 'cultural tsars.'
congruence_and_disruptions.healing_disruption: The 'William' anecdote serves as a healing disruption, forcing the 'clean' congregation to see the Gospel in the 'unwashed' neighbor.

reception_simulation.the_factual_ear_hears: Christianity is not a religion of rules but a message of God's relational intervention in history.
reception_simulation.the_relational_ear_hears: The preacher is one of us; he struggles with prayer and feels the pressure of the culture, just like I do.
reception_simulation.the_appeal_ear_hears: I don't have to be 'spiritual' to be accepted by God; I should share this relief with others.
reception_simulation.the_self_revelation_ear_hears: This man is intellectually sophisticated but finds his true identity in being a 'sinner saved by grace'.

overall_picture.summary: This sermon is a sophisticated application of Barthian 'extra nos' theology within a specific cultural moment. The preacher successfully navigates the tension between the 'Blue' side (the doctrine of the Trinity) and the 'Green' side (personal authenticity) by defining the Trinity as a relational event of grace. He avoids the 'Compulsive' trap of dogmatic lecturing by employing a 'Depressive' warmth that seeks to include the 'unspiritual.' The theological 'Sache'—that God justifies the ungodly—is the clear center. The sermon's greatest strength is its refusal to turn the Gospel into a moralistic appeal for 'tolerance,' instead grounding 'multiculturalism' in the ontological reality of the Trinity. While it occasionally veers into cultural polemics, it remains a potent example of 'diaconal' preaching where the preacher's ego is transparently offered as a vessel for the promise.
overall_picture.barthian_warning: Low risk. The preacher explicitly warns against 'spirituality' and 'religion' as human constructs, keeping God as the Acting Subject.
top_3_strengths: Radical focus on Zuspruch (Promise) over Anspruch (Demand).
top_3_improvement_points: Reduce the 'us vs. them' framing regarding secular culture.
Deepen the exegetical engagement with the Matthean text.
Provide more concrete 'Red' side applications for the congregation's witness.
overall_picture.conclusion: A strong, congruent sermon that serves the Truth by deconstructing the preacher's own religious authority.
